ch.name: Chain
ch.description: The foundation stitch used to start most crochet projects
ch.instructions: Yarn over, pull through loop on hook

sl_st.name: Slip Stitch
sl_st.description: The shortest stitch, used for joining and moving without adding height
sl_st.instructions: Insert hook into stitch, yarn over, pull through both loops on hook in one motion

sc.name: Single Crochet
sc.description: A dense, short stitch ideal for solid fabrics
sc.instructions: Insert hook into stitch, yarn over, pull up loop (2 loops on hook), yarn over, pull through both loops

hdc.name: Half Double Crochet
hdc.description: Taller than single crochet, shorter than double crochet
hdc.instructions: Yarn over, insert hook, yarn over, pull up loop (3 loops on hook), yarn over, pull through all 3 loops

dc.name: Double Crochet
dc.description: A tall, flexible stitch creating open, drapey fabric
dc.instructions: Yarn over, insert hook, yarn over, pull up loop, yarn over, pull through 2 loops, yarn over, pull through last 2 loops

tr.name: Treble Crochet
tr.description: The tallest basic stitch, creating very open fabric
tr.instructions: Yarn over twice, insert hook, yarn over, pull up loop, [yarn over, pull through 2 loops] 3 times

bobble.description: A raised bump created by multiple partial stitches worked together
bobble.instructions: Work 3-5 partial double crochets in same stitch, yarn over, pull through all loops on hook

cluster.description: Multiple complete stitches worked together at the top
cluster.instructions: Work 2-4 stitches leaving last loop of each on hook, yarn over, pull through all loops

popcorn.description: Multiple stitches in same place joined at the top
popcorn.instructions: Work 4-5 dc in same stitch, remove hook from loop, insert in top of first dc, pull working loop through

shell.description: A fan-like group of stitches worked in same space
shell.instructions: Work specified number of stitches (usually 5-7 dc) in same stitch or space

puff.description: A puffy stitch created by multiple yarn overs
puff.instructions: Yarn over, insert hook, pull up loop, repeat 3-5 times in same stitch, yarn over, pull through all loops

fpdc.name: Front Post Double Crochet
fpdc.description: Creates a raised vertical line on the front
fpdc.instructions: Yarn over, insert hook from front to back to front around post of designated stitch, complete as normal dc

bpdc.name: Back Post Double Crochet
bpdc.description: Creates a recessed line, with raised line appearing on back
bpdc.instructions: Yarn over, insert hook from back to front to back around post of designated stitch, complete as normal dc

inc.name: Increase
inc.description: Work 2 or more stitches in same stitch to increase stitch count
inc.instructions: Work 2 stitches of same type in same stitch from previous row

dec.name: Decrease
dec.description: Work 2 or more stitches together to reduce stitch count
dec.instructions: Draw up loops in 2 stitches, yarn over, pull through all loops

sc2tog.name: Single Crochet 2 Together
sc2tog.description: Decrease by working 2 single crochets together
sc2tog.instructions: Insert hook in first stitch, pull up loop, insert hook in next stitch, pull up loop, yarn over, pull through all 3 loops

invisible_decrease.name: Invisible Decrease
invisible_decrease.description: A decrease method that creates a neater finish for amigurumi
invisible_decrease.instructions: Insert hook under front loops only of next 2 stitches, yarn over, pull through both loops, yarn over, pull through 2 loops on hook

chart_basics.description: Crochet symbol charts show spatial relationships of stitches
chart_basics.reading_direction: Read charts from bottom to top, right to left for rows, counterclockwise for rounds
chart_basics.starting_point: Often marked with arrow or number

us_vs_uk_terms.note: US terms are generally one step shorter than UK terms

cyc_system.description: Craft Yarn Council standardized yarn weight system using categories 0-7

wpi_measurement.description: Wraps Per Inch - method to measure yarn thickness
wpi_measurement.how_to_measure: Wrap yarn around ruler for 1 inch, count wraps
tips: Use for unlabeled or handspun yarns

stitches_per_inch.formula: Stitches per inch = Number of stitches counted / Width in inches
stitches_per_inch.example: If 20 stitches measure 4 inches: 20 ÷ 4 = 5 stitches per inch

rows_per_inch.formula: Rows per inch = Number of rows counted / Height in inches
rows_per_inch.example: If 16 rows measure 4 inches: 16 ÷ 4 = 4 rows per inch

stitch_count_calculation.formula: Required stitches = Desired width (inches) × Stitches per inch
stitch_count_calculation.example: For 10-inch width at 5 stitches per inch: 10 × 5 = 50 stitches needed

row_count_calculation.formula: Required rows = Desired height (inches) × Rows per inch
row_count_calculation.example: For 8-inch height at 4 rows per inch: 8 × 4 = 32 rows needed

gauge_swatch_process.step_1: Use project yarn, hook, and stitch pattern
gauge_swatch_process.step_2: Make swatch at least 4×4 inches (preferably 5×5 inches)
gauge_swatch_process.step_3: Block swatch as you would final project
gauge_swatch_process.step_4: Lay flat on hard surface without stretching
gauge_swatch_process.step_6: Count stitches horizontally and rows vertically

adjustments.too_many_stitches: Use larger hook to loosen gauge
adjustments.too_few_stitches: Use smaller hook to tighten gauge

ease_calculations.positive_ease: Garment larger than body measurement for loose fit
ease_calculations.negative_ease: Garment smaller than body measurement for tight fit
ease_calculations.ease_formula: Finished measurement = Body measurement + Ease allowance

crown_formula.alternative_formula: Head circumference ÷ (1.1 × π) for 10% stretch factor

construction_method.top_down: Start with crown, increase to full circumference, then work even for sides
construction_method.bottom_up: Start with band, work up to crown, then decrease to close
construction_method.side_to_side: Work from ear to ear, seam at back

hats.crown_shaping: Start with 6-12 stitches in magic ring, increase evenly until desired diameter reached

construction_tips.length_guide: Use arm span as rough guide for length
construction_tips.width_considerations: Wider scarves for fashion, narrower for warmth

calculation_process.step_2: Measure stitches and rows per inch
calculation_process.step_3: Calculate total stitches needed: width × stitches per inch
calculation_process.step_4: Calculate total rows needed: length × rows per inch
calculation_process.step_5: Adjust for stitch multiples if using patterned stitches
calculation_process.step_6: Add turning chains to row count

basic_anatomy.head: Usually largest part, often a sphere
basic_anatomy.body: Can be sphere, cylinder, or pear shape
basic_anatomy.ears_details: Small shapes attached after main construction

construction_principles.work_in_spiral: Continuous rounds without joining for smooth shaping
construction_principles.stuff_as_you_go: Stuff before opening gets too small
construction_principles.invisible_finish: Use invisible decrease for neat closure

basic_shapes.sphere: Start with 6 sc in magic ring, increase 6 stitches per round until desired size, work even rounds, then decrease
basic_shapes.cylinder: Start with desired circumference, work even throughout
basic_shapes.cone: Start small, increase gradually to desired size

safety_considerations.use_safety_eyes: Safer than buttons for young children
safety_considerations.check_for_gaps: Stuffing should not show through stitches

increase_formulas.even_spacing_formula: (Desired end stitch count ÷ Increase number) - 2 = Stitches between increases
increase_formulas.example: To go from 20 to 24 stitches (4 increases): 24 ÷ 4 = 6, 6 - 2 = 4 stitches between each increase
process: Adjust for non-divisible numbers by distributing extras

decrease_formulas.even_spacing_formula: (Current stitch count ÷ Decrease number) - 2 = Stitches between decreases
decrease_formulas.example: To go from 24 to 18 stitches (6 decreases): 24 ÷ 6 = 4, 4 - 2 = 2 stitches between each decrease
decrease_formulas.invisible_decrease: Insert hook under front loops only of 2 stitches, yarn over, pull through both, yarn over, pull through 2 loops

raglan_shaping.basic_concept: Diagonal seams from neck to underarm, increases at 4 raglan lines
raglan_shaping.standard_increase: 8 stitches per increase round (2 at each raglan line)

stitch_distribution.sleeve_stitches: About 30% of back neck stitches each

compound_raglan.concept: Varying increase rates for better fit
compound_raglan.pattern: Fast increases for shoulders, slower for mid-yoke, potentially faster again near underarm

asymmetric_raglan.concept: Different increase rates for front vs back
asymmetric_raglan.reason: Back body typically longer than front
asymmetric_raglan.method: Add short rows or extra increases at back neck

basic_method.increase_phase: Increase 6 stitches per round until desired diameter
basic_method.middle_phase: Work even rounds (no increases/decreases) equal to increase rounds plus one
basic_method.decrease_phase: Decrease 6 stitches per round, mirroring increase pattern

round_vs_angular.round_method: Offset increases in every other round to prevent corners
round_vs_angular.angular_method: Stack increases directly above previous round (creates hexagonal shape)

increase_rounds_example: Round 2: Increase in each stitch (12 stitches)
finishing_tips: Stuff before opening gets too small
Use invisible decrease for neater finish
Pull yarn tail through remaining stitches to close

garment_waist_shaping.method: Decrease from bust to waist, then increase from waist to hip

sleeve_shaping.method: Increase from wrist to underarm for fitted sleeve
sleeve_shaping.rate: Typically increase 2 stitches every few rows

hat_crown_to_brim.crown: Start with flat circle to desired diameter
hat_crown_to_brim.brim: May increase slightly for flare or work even for straight

circular_vs_flat_shaping.flat: Increases/decreases typically at edges or specific points

troubleshooting.uneven_edges: Count stitches frequently and use stitch markers
troubleshooting.curling_fabric: Adjust hook size or use different edge treatment
